description: From New Latin microscopium, from Ancient Greek μικρός (mikrós, “small”) + σκοπέω (skopéō, “I look at”).

entries.meaning: An optical instrument used for observing small objects.
examples: That he might ascertain whether any of the cloths of ancient Egypt were made of hemp, M. Dutrochet has examined with the microscope the weavable filaments of this last vegetable.

entries.meaning: Any instrument for imaging very small objects (such as an electron microscope).

verbs.description: microscope (third-person singular simple present microscopes, present participle microscoping, simple past and past participle microscoped)

entries.meaning: To examine with a microscope, to put under a microscope (literally or figuratively).
